title: Biotechnology
description: The use of living organisms or biological systems to develop useful products. (e.g., vaccine or antibiotics production)

title: Traditional Biotechnology
description: Early biotechnology methods like fermentation and selective breeding. (e.g., bread making, cheese production)

title: Modern Biotechnology
description: Use of advanced techniques like genetic engineering and CRISPR. (e.g., gene therapy, recombinant insulin)

title: Genetic Engineering
description: Altering the genetic makeup of organisms for desired traits. (e.g., Bt cotton for pest resistance)

title: Recombinant DNA Technology
description: Combining DNA from different sources to create modified organisms. (e.g., human insulin production in bacteria)

title: Industrial Biotechnology
description: Use of biotechnology in manufacturing and industry. (e.g., enzyme production in detergents)

title: Medical Biotechnology
description: Application of biotechnology in healthcare. (e.g., monoclonal antibodies for cancer treatment)

title: Agricultural Biotechnology
description: Improving crops and livestock using biotechnological methods. (e.g., genetically modified crops)

title: Environmental Biotechnology
description: Using biotechnology for environmental protection. (e.g., bioremediation of oil spills)

title: Marine Biotechnology
description: Utilizing marine organisms for industrial and pharmaceutical applications. (e.g., algae-based biofuels)

title: Plant Biotechnology
description: Improving plants through genetic modification or tissue culture. (e.g., Golden Rice with enhanced vitamin A)

title: Animal Biotechnology
description: Genetic modification and cloning of animals. (e.g., cloning of sheep Dolly)

title: Microbial Biotechnology
description: Using microorganisms for various applications. (e.g., probiotics for gut health)

title: Pharmaceutical Biotechnology
description: Developing drugs and vaccines through biotech methods. (e.g., mRNA COVID-19 vaccines)

title: Tissue Engineering
description: Growing tissues and organs using biotechnology. (e.g., artificial skin for burn victims)

title: Stem Cell Technology
description: Using stem cells to regenerate damaged tissues. (e.g., stem cell therapy for spinal injuries)

title: Bioinformatics
description: Using computers to analyze biological data. (e.g., genome sequencing of humans)

title: Nanobiotechnology
description: Applying nanotechnology to biological systems. (e.g., nanoparticle drug delivery systems)

title: Synthetic Biology
description: Designing and constructing new biological parts and systems. (e.g., artificial bacteria for biofuel production)

title: Bioprocessing
description: Using biological materials to manufacture products. (e.g., fermentation of antibiotics)

title: Gene Cloning
description: Creating identical copies of a gene. (e.g., cloning insulin genes in bacteria)

title: Genome Editing
description: Modifying genes using tools like CRISPR-Cas9. (e.g., correcting genetic disorders in humans)

title: Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs)
description: Organisms with altered DNA. (e.g., pest-resistant corn)

title: Transgenic Organisms
description: Organisms with genes from other species. (e.g., glow-in-the-dark fish with jellyfish genes)

title: Biopharmaceuticals
description: Drugs produced using biotechnology. (e.g., insulin for diabetes treatment)

title: Fermentation
description: Microbial conversion of substances into useful products. (e.g., yogurt production)

title: Probiotics
description: Beneficial bacteria that promote gut health. (e.g., Lactobacillus in yogurt)

title: Prebiotics
description: Non-digestible food components that promote beneficial microbes. (e.g., fiber in bananas)

title: Biofuels
description: Fuels derived from biological sources. (e.g., ethanol from sugarcane)

title: Biodegradable Plastics
description: Plastics made from biological materials that decompose naturally. (e.g., PLA made from corn starch)

title: Insulin Production
description: Producing human insulin using genetically modified bacteria. (e.g., Humulin)

title: Gene Therapy
description: Correcting defective genes to treat diseases. (e.g., treating sickle cell anemia)

title: Monoclonal Antibodies
description: Lab-made antibodies for disease treatment. (e.g., cancer immunotherapy)

title: Bioremediation
description: Using microbes to clean pollution. (e.g., oil-eating bacteria for oil spills)

title: Bioleaching
description: Extracting metals from ores using microbes. (e.g., copper recovery from mines)

title: Tissue Culture
description: Growing plant cells in artificial conditions. (e.g., orchid propagation in labs)

title: Bt Crops
description: Crops modified with Bacillus thuringiensis gene for pest resistance. (e.g., Bt cotton)

title: Golden Rice
description: Genetically engineered rice with high vitamin A content. (e.g., reducing vitamin A deficiency)

title: Bioplastics
description: Environment-friendly plastics made from renewable resources. (e.g., corn-based PLA bottles)

title: Lab-grown Meat
description: Meat produced in labs from animal cells. (e.g., cultured chicken nuggets)

title: CRISPR Gene Editing
description: Revolutionary technology for precise DNA modification. (e.g., fixing genetic disorders)

title: Artificial Organs
description: Using biotechnology to create organs for transplants. (e.g., lab-grown kidneys)

title: DNA Vaccines
description: Vaccines that use DNA to generate an immune response. (e.g., Zika virus vaccine trials)

title: Personalized Medicine
description: Tailoring medical treatments based on genetics. (e.g., cancer therapies based on DNA testing)

title: Biochips
description: Microchips that analyze biological samples. (e.g., disease detection chips)

title: Smart Drugs
description: Biotech drugs that target specific cells. (e.g., targeted cancer therapies)

title: Artificial Photosynthesis
description: Using synthetic methods to mimic plant photosynthesis. (e.g., carbon-neutral fuel production)

title: Edible Vaccines
description: Vaccines developed in food crops. (e.g., banana-based hepatitis vaccine research)

title: 3D Bioprinting
description: Printing tissues and organs using bioprinting technology. (e.g., printing skin grafts)

title: Neurobiotechnology
description: Biotechnology applied to brain research. (e.g., brain-computer interfaces for paralyzed patients)

title: DNA Replication
description: Process of making an identical copy of DNA. (e.g., occurs in cell division)

title: Transcription
description: Process where DNA is copied into RNA. (e.g., formation of mRNA in the nucleus)

title: Translation
description: Process where RNA is used to make proteins. (e.g., ribosomes producing insulin protein)

title: Mutations
description: Changes in DNA sequence that can cause diseases. (e.g., sickle cell anemia mutation)

title: Gene Expression
description: The process by which genes are turned on or off. (e.g., hormone production in stress conditions)

title: Plasmid DNA
description: Small circular DNA in bacteria used in cloning. (e.g., pBR322 plasmid in gene cloning)

title: Restriction Enzymes
description: Enzymes that cut DNA at specific sites. (e.g., EcoRI used in genetic engineering)

title: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
description: A technique to amplify DNA. (e.g., used in COVID-19 testing)

title: Gel Electrophoresis
description: A method to separate DNA fragments. (e.g., used in forensic DNA fingerprinting)

title: DNA Sequencing
description: Determining the exact sequence of nucleotides in DNA. (e.g., Human Genome Project)

title: Microbiology
description: Study of microorganisms like bacteria and fungi. (e.g., E. coli in gut health research)

title: Pathogen
description: A microorganism that causes disease. (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis causes TB)

title: Probiotic Bacteria
description: Beneficial bacteria that aid digestion. (e.g., Lactobacillus in yogurt)

title: Yeast Fermentation
description: Conversion of sugar into alcohol by yeast. (e.g., beer and wine production)

title: Antibiotic Production
description: Use of microbes to produce medicines. (e.g., Penicillium mold producing penicillin)

title: Biopesticides
description: Natural substances that control pests. (e.g., Bacillus thuringiensis as an insecticide)

title: Bacteriophages
description: Viruses that infect and kill bacteria. (e.g., used in phage therapy for bacterial infections)

title: Single-Cell Protein
description: Protein produced by microbes for food. (e.g., Spirulina as a high-protein supplement)

title: Biofilms
description: Microbial communities forming protective layers. (e.g., dental plaque caused by bacteria)

title: Quorum Sensing
description: Bacterial communication to coordinate behavior. (e.g., Vibrio cholerae in cholera infection)

title: Green Biotechnology
description: Application of biotechnology in agriculture. (e.g., development of drought-resistant crops)

title: Biofertilizers
description: Microorganisms that improve soil fertility. (e.g., Rhizobium for nitrogen fixation in legumes)

title: Hydroponics
description: Growing plants without soil using nutrient solutions. (e.g., lettuce farming in water-based systems)

title: Aeroponics
description: Growing plants in mist environments without soil. (e.g., NASA experiments for space farming)

title: Vermicomposting
description: Using earthworms to convert organic waste into compost. (e.g., composting kitchen waste into fertilizer)

title: Carbon Sequestration
description: Capturing carbon dioxide to reduce global warming. (e.g., algae-based CO₂ absorption techniques)

title: Genetically Engineered Crops
description: Crops with improved traits through gene modification. (e.g., herbicide-resistant soybean)

title: Drought-Resistant Crops
description: Crops modified to survive with less water. (e.g., drought-resistant maize varieties)

title: Biodegradable Waste
description: Organic waste that decomposes naturally. (e.g., banana peels breaking down into compost)

title: Water Bioremediation
description: Using microbes to clean polluted water. (e.g., bacteria removing oil spills in oceans)

title: Pharmacogenomics
description: Study of how genes affect drug response. (e.g., personalized cancer treatment)

title: DNA Vaccines
description: Vaccines that use genetic material to trigger immunity. (e.g., Zika virus vaccine trials)

title: mRNA Vaccines
description: Vaccines using messenger RNA to generate immunity. (e.g., Pfizer and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines)

title: Gene Therapy
description: Treating diseases by replacing faulty genes. (e.g., treating hemophilia with gene therapy)

title: Monoclonal Antibodies
description: Lab-made antibodies targeting specific diseases. (e.g., cancer treatment drugs like Rituximab)

title: Bioartificial Organs
description: Synthetic organs developed using biotechnology. (e.g., artificial pancreas for diabetes patients)

title: Regenerative Medicine
description: Healing damaged tissues using biotechnology. (e.g., stem cell therapy for heart disease)

title: Xenotransplantation
description: Transplanting animal organs into humans. (e.g., pig heart transplant trials)

title: Medical Imaging in Biotechnology
description: Using imaging technology for disease detection. (e.g., MRI for brain scans)

title: CRISPR-Based Cancer Therapy
description: Using CRISPR to edit cancer-related genes. (e.g., clinical trials on lung cancer patients)

title: Biosensors
description: Devices that detect biological molecules. (e.g., glucose biosensors for diabetes monitoring)

title: Wearable Biotech Devices
description: Technology worn on the body for health monitoring. (e.g., smartwatches tracking heart rate)

title: Personalized Genomics
description: Tailoring medical treatments to individual genetic profiles. (e.g., DNA-based diet plans)

title: Organoid Cultures
description: Lab-grown miniature organs for research. (e.g., brain organoids for studying neurological diseases)

title: Lab-Grown Blood
description: Artificial blood created using biotechnology. (e.g., research into blood transfusion alternatives)

title: Space Biotechnology
description: Using biotechnology in space exploration. (e.g., growing plants on Mars for future missions)

title: Human Longevity Research
description: Using biotechnology to extend lifespan. (e.g., anti-aging therapies based on genetic studies)

title: Neural Implants
description: Devices implanted in the brain for neurological conditions. (e.g., brain-computer interfaces for paralysis patients)

title: DNA-Based Data Storage
description: Storing digital information in DNA molecules. (e.g., encoding text files in synthetic DNA)

title: Biological Robots (BioBots)
description: Living robots made from biological tissues. (e.g., xenobots for medical applications)

title: Chromosome
description: A structure made of DNA carrying genetic information. (e.g., humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes)

title: Histones
description: Proteins that help package DNA into chromosomes. (e.g., H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 histones in eukaryotic cells)

title: Codon
description: A set of three nucleotides coding for an amino acid. (e.g., AUG codes for methionine in protein synthesis)

title: Genotype
description: The genetic makeup of an organism. (e.g., BB, Bb, or bb for eye color genes)

title: Phenotype
description: The physical expression of genes. (e.g., blue or brown eyes based on genotype)

title: Operon
description: A gene regulatory system in bacteria. (e.g., lac operon in E. coli controls lactose metabolism)

title: Promoter
description: A DNA sequence where RNA polymerase binds to start transcription. (e.g., TATA box in eukaryotes)

title: Enhancer
description: A DNA sequence that increases gene expression. (e.g., enhancers in hormone-regulated genes)

title: Exons
description: Coding sequences in genes that form proteins. (e.g., human insulin gene exons code for insulin production)

title: Introns
description: Non-coding sequences removed from RNA. (e.g., introns are spliced out before translation in humans)

title: Upstream Processing
description: Preparation of biological materials before fermentation. (e.g., sterilization of media for microbial growth)

title: Downstream Processing
description: Purification of biotech products. (e.g., protein purification from bacterial cultures)

title: Biofermenter
description: A device for large-scale microbial culture. (e.g., producing antibiotics using fermentation tanks)

title: Batch Culture
description: A closed system where microbes grow until nutrients run out. (e.g., batch fermentation of penicillin)

title: Continuous Culture
description: A system where fresh nutrients are added, and waste is removed continuously. (e.g., industrial ethanol production)

title: Immobilized Enzymes
description: Enzymes attached to a solid support for reuse. (e.g., lactase immobilized for lactose-free milk production)

title: Microbial Enzymes
description: Enzymes produced by microbes for industrial use. (e.g., amylase from Bacillus used in starch breakdown)

title: Bioethanol
description: Alcohol produced from biomass fermentation. (e.g., sugarcane-based ethanol for fuel)

title: Biogas
description: Renewable energy from microbial digestion of waste. (e.g., methane from anaerobic digestion of organic waste)

title: Biosurfactants
description: Microbial compounds that reduce surface tension. (e.g., rhamnolipids used in oil spill cleanup)

title: DNA Library
description: A collection of DNA fragments stored for research. (e.g., human genome libraries for gene studies)

title: cDNA (Complementary DNA)
description: DNA synthesized from mRNA using reverse transcriptase. (e.g., used in gene cloning and expression studies)

title: Vector
description: A carrier molecule used to transfer genetic material. (e.g., plasmids and viral vectors in gene therapy)

title: Transformation
description: The introduction of foreign DNA into a cell. (e.g., inserting genes into bacteria for insulin production)

title: Transfection
description: The introduction of DNA into eukaryotic cells. (e.g., transfecting human cells with a cancer-fighting gene)

title: Southern Blotting
description: A technique to detect specific DNA sequences. (e.g., used in forensic DNA fingerprinting)

title: Northern Blotting
description: A technique to study RNA molecules. (e.g., analyzing gene expression in tissues)

title: Western Blotting
description: A method to detect proteins. (e.g., used in HIV diagnosis tests)

title: Microarray Technology
description: A tool for analyzing gene expression. (e.g., comparing cancerous vs. normal cells in research)

title: Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS)
description: A high-throughput DNA sequencing method. (e.g., used in whole genome sequencing projects)

title: Biomining
description: Using microbes to extract metals from ores. (e.g., copper extraction using Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans)

title: Biosorption
description: Using biological materials to remove heavy metals. (e.g., algae removing lead from wastewater)

title: Phytoremediation
description: Using plants to clean up pollutants. (e.g., sunflower plants absorbing heavy metals in contaminated soil)

title: Genetic Pollution
description: Uncontrolled spread of genetically modified genes. (e.g., crossbreeding of GMO and wild plants)

title: Eutrophication
description: Excess nutrients causing algal blooms in water. (e.g., agricultural runoff leading to fish die-offs)

title: Bioaugmentation
description: Adding specific microbes to speed up degradation of pollutants. (e.g., oil-degrading bacteria in oil spills)

title: Composting
description: The natural breakdown of organic waste into fertilizer. (e.g., converting food waste into nutrient-rich soil compost)

title: Biodiesel
description: A renewable fuel made from plant oils or algae. (e.g., soybean oil-based biodiesel for vehicles)

title: Electrobiotechnology
description: Using microbes to generate electricity. (e.g., microbial fuel cells powered by bacteria)

title: Plastic-Degrading Bacteria
description: Microbes capable of breaking down plastics. (e.g., Ideonella sakaiensis consuming PET plastic)

title: Bioethics
description: The study of ethical issues in biotechnology. (e.g., debates on human cloning ethics)

title: Intellectual Property Rights (IPR)
description: Legal protection for biotech inventions. (e.g., patents for genetically modified crops)

title: Biosafety
description: Precautions to prevent biotech risks. (e.g., containment measures for GMO research labs)

title: Genetic Privacy
description: Protection of an individual's genetic data. (e.g., concerns over unauthorized DNA testing)

title: Biopiracy
description: Exploiting biological resources without proper permission. (e.g., companies patenting indigenous medicinal plants)

title: Informed Consent
description: Ethical requirement for participants in biotech research. (e.g., obtaining consent for genetic testing)

title: GMO Labeling
description: Informing consumers about genetically modified food content. (e.g., mandatory GMO labels in some countries)

title: Cloning Ethics
description: Moral concerns about creating genetic copies. (e.g., ethical debates on human cloning)

title: Regenerative Medicine Policies
description: Legal frameworks for stem cell research. (e.g., laws governing embryo-derived stem cells)

title: CRISPR Regulation
description: Guidelines for gene editing research. (e.g., legal restrictions on human germline editing)

title: Synthetic Biology
description: Designing and constructing new biological systems. (e.g., synthetic bacteria producing biofuels)

title: Minimal Genome
description: A genome with only essential genes for life. (e.g., Mycoplasma mycoides with a synthetic minimal genome)

title: Biobricks
description: Standardized DNA sequences used in synthetic biology. (e.g., promoters, ribosome binding sites in genetic circuits)

title: Artificial Life
description: Life forms created entirely through synthetic means. (e.g., Craig Venter’s synthetic bacterial genome)

title: Gene Circuit
description: A network of genes functioning like an electronic circuit. (e.g., synthetic toggle switches in bacteria)

title: Metabolic Engineering
description: Modifying metabolic pathways for better productivity. (e.g., yeast engineered to produce artemisinin for malaria treatment)

title: Smart Biomaterials
description: Materials that respond to biological signals. (e.g., self-healing hydrogels used in wound healing)

title: Living Sensors
description: Engineered organisms detecting environmental pollutants. (e.g., bacteria detecting arsenic in water)

title: Biosynthetic Pathways
description: Cellular processes for producing biomolecules. (e.g., insulin biosynthesis in genetically modified bacteria)

title: 3D Bioprinting
description: Printing living tissues layer by layer. (e.g., bio-printed skin for burn victims)

title: Nanobiotechnology
description: Using nanotechnology in biological applications. (e.g., gold nanoparticles in cancer therapy)

title: Quantum Dots
description: Nanoparticles used for imaging cells. (e.g., fluorescent quantum dots in tumor detection)

title: Nano Drug Delivery
description: Targeted medicine transport using nanotechnology. (e.g., liposomes delivering chemotherapy drugs)

title: DNA Origami
description: Folding DNA into nanoscale structures. (e.g., DNA nanorobots for targeted drug release)

title: Nanobiosensors
description: Nanoscale sensors detecting biomolecules. (e.g., glucose nanosensors for diabetes monitoring)

title: Dendrimers
description: Branched nanoparticles used in drug delivery. (e.g., dendrimers carrying anticancer drugs to tumors)

title: Fullerenes
description: Carbon nanostructures with biomedical uses. (e.g., fullerenes in antioxidant therapy)

title: Nanoshells
description: Hollow nanoparticles for precise heating of cancer cells. (e.g., photothermal therapy using gold nanoshells)

title: Biocompatible Nanomaterials
description: Materials safe for biological use. (e.g., silver nanoparticles in wound dressings)

title: Nanozymes
description: Nanomaterials mimicking enzyme activity. (e.g., iron oxide nanozymes replacing natural peroxidases)

title: Bioinformatics
description: Using computers to analyze biological data. (e.g., sequence analysis using BLAST)

title: Computational Biology
description: Using algorithms to study biological systems. (e.g., modeling protein structures in drug discovery)

title: Machine Learning in Biotech
description: AI predicting biological patterns. (e.g., AI predicting protein interactions in diseases)

title: Deep Learning in Genomics
description: AI analyzing complex genetic data. (e.g., deep learning for cancer mutation detection)

title: Molecular Docking
description: Computer-based drug-receptor interaction modeling. (e.g., designing COVID-19 antiviral drugs)

title: Biological Databases
description: Online resources storing biological information. (e.g., GenBank for DNA sequences)

title: Protein Folding Simulation
description: AI predicting protein structures. (e.g., AlphaFold predicting 3D protein structures)

title: CRISPR Data Analysis
description: AI optimizing gene-editing targets. (e.g., software predicting CRISPR-Cas9 efficiency)

title: Digital Twin Biology
description: Virtual models of living systems. (e.g., digital twins of organs for medical testing)

title: Personalized AI Healthcare
description: AI tailoring treatments based on genetics. (e.g., AI recommending cancer therapies based on mutations)

title: Space Biotechnology
description: Using biotech for space research. (e.g., growing plants on the ISS)

title: Astrobiology
description: Study of life’s existence beyond Earth. (e.g., searching for microbial life on Mars)

title: Extremophiles
description: Microbes surviving in extreme conditions. (e.g., Thermus aquaticus living in hot springs)

title: Radiation-Resistant Microbes
description: Organisms surviving high radiation. (e.g., Deinococcus radiodurans withstands space radiation)

title: Microgravity Effects on Cells
description: Studying how cells behave in zero gravity. (e.g., muscle atrophy studies in astronauts)

title: Bioregenerative Life Support
description: Using biotech to sustain life in space. (e.g., algae producing oxygen in space habitats)

title: Space Synthetic Biology
description: Engineering microbes for space use. (e.g., synthetic bacteria producing bioplastics in space)

title: Martian Soil Biotech
description: Using microbes to make Mars soil fertile. (e.g., cyanobacteria enhancing Martian soil nutrients)

title: Microbial Fuel Cells in Space
description: Generating electricity from microbes in zero gravity. (e.g., space bio-batteries for energy)

title: Terraforming Biotech
description: Modifying planets for human survival. (e.g., using microbes to produce oxygen on Mars)

title: Artificial Intelligence in Drug Discovery
description: AI speeding up new drug development. (e.g., AI-designed COVID-19 antivirals)

title: Gene Drive Technology
description: Spreading genetic traits in populations. (e.g., gene drive to eliminate malaria mosquitoes)

title: Lab-Grown Meat
description: Cultivated meat without killing animals. (e.g., lab-grown beef as a sustainable protein source)

title: Biofoundries
description: Automated labs producing synthetic organisms. (e.g., biofoundries designing custom bacteria for industry)

title: Biological Warfare Prevention
description: Using biotech to prevent bioterrorism. (e.g., rapid detection of bioweapons using DNA sequencing)

title: Climate-Resilient Crops
description: Genetically modified crops tolerating extreme weather. (e.g., salt-tolerant rice for coastal farming)

title: Sustainable Biomanufacturing
description: Using microbes to make eco-friendly products. (e.g., biodegradable plastics from bacteria)

title: Human Organs on Chips
description: Microfluidic chips mimicking human organs. (e.g., lung-on-a-chip for drug testing)

title: Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs)
description: Connecting the brain to computers. (e.g., Neuralink for restoring movement in paralysis patients)

title: Biotech for Aging
description: Research on extending human lifespan. (e.g., anti-aging gene therapies targeting cellular aging mechanisms)

title: Carbohydrate
description: Organic molecules made of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen that provide energy. (e.g., glucose, starch, cellulose)

title: Monosaccharide
description: The simplest sugar with one unit. (e.g., glucose, fructose, galactose)

title: Disaccharide
description: A sugar formed by two monosaccharides. (e.g., sucrose = glucose + fructose)

title: Polysaccharide
description: A long chain of monosaccharides. (e.g., starch, glycogen, cellulose)

title: Glucose
description: A simple sugar used as the primary energy source. (e.g., found in honey, fruits, and blood)

title: Fructose
description: A fruit sugar that is sweeter than glucose. (e.g., found in apples and honey)

title: Sucrose
description: A common table sugar made of glucose and fructose. (e.g., found in sugarcane and sugar beets)

title: Lactose
description: A milk sugar composed of glucose and galactose. (e.g., found in dairy products)

title: Glycogen
description: A storage form of glucose in animals. (e.g., stored in liver and muscles)

title: Cellulose
description: A structural carbohydrate in plants that humans cannot digest. (e.g., present in plant cell walls and paper)

title: Protein
description: Large biomolecules made of amino acids that perform essential functions. (e.g., enzymes, hormones, antibodies)

title: Amino Acid
description: The building blocks of proteins. (e.g., glycine, alanine, tryptophan)

title: Peptide Bond
description: A bond linking amino acids in proteins. (e.g., found in insulin and hemoglobin)

title: Enzyme
description: A protein that speeds up chemical reactions. (e.g., amylase breaking down starch into sugar)

title: Hormone
description: A signaling protein regulating body processes. (e.g., insulin controlling blood sugar levels)

title: Haemoglobin
description: A protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. (e.g., binds oxygen in lungs and releases it in tissues)

title: Keratin
description: A structural protein in hair, nails, and skin. (e.g., found in human hair and animal hooves)

title: Collagen
description: The main structural protein in connective tissues. (e.g., present in skin, tendons, and cartilage)

title: Denaturation
description: The loss of protein structure due to heat or chemicals. (e.g., cooking eggs causes denaturation of proteins)

title: Essential Amino Acids
description: Amino acids that must be obtained from diet. (e.g., lysine, leucine, tryptophan in meat, eggs, and dairy)

title: Lipid
description: A hydrophobic biomolecule used for energy storage and membranes. (e.g., fats, oils, steroids)

title: Fatty Acid
description: A component of fats with a long hydrocarbon chain. (e.g., palmitic acid in palm oil)

title: Triglyceride
description: A lipid made of glycerol and three fatty acids. (e.g., stored in body fat and vegetable oils)

title: Phospholipid
description: A lipid forming cell membranes. (e.g., lecithin in egg yolks and soybeans)

title: Steroid
description: A lipid with a four-ring structure. (e.g., cholesterol, testosterone, estrogen)

title: Saturated Fat
description: A fat with no double bonds, solid at room temperature. (e.g., butter, coconut oil)

title: Unsaturated Fat
description: A fat with one or more double bonds, liquid at room temperature. (e.g., olive oil, fish oil)

title: Cholesterol
description: A lipid important for cell membranes and hormones. (e.g., found in eggs, meat, and dairy products)

title: Waxes
description: Lipids that form protective coatings. (e.g., beeswax, earwax, plant cuticles)

title: Omega-3 Fatty Acid
description: A healthy fat that reduces inflammation. (e.g., found in fish, flaxseeds, walnuts)

title: Nucleic Acid
description: A biomolecule that stores and transmits genetic information. (e.g., DNA, RNA)

title: DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)
description: The molecule carrying genetic instructions. (e.g., found in the nucleus of cells)

title: RNA (Ribonucleic Acid)
description: A nucleic acid involved in protein synthesis. (e.g., mRNA, tRNA, rRNA in translation)

title: Nucleotide
description: The building block of nucleic acids. (e.g., adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine in DNA)

title: Double Helix
description: The twisted ladder structure of DNA. (e.g., discovered by Watson and Crick in 1953)

title: mRNA (Messenger RNA)
description: Carries genetic code from DNA to ribosomes. (e.g., involved in COVID-19 vaccine development)

title: tRNA (Transfer RNA)
description: Brings amino acids to ribosomes. (e.g., essential in protein synthesis)

title: rRNA (Ribosomal RNA)
description: Forms part of ribosomes. (e.g., key component of ribosomal subunits in cells)

title: Genetic Code
description: The sequence of nucleotides that determines protein synthesis. (e.g., AUG is the start codon for translation)

title: Mutation
description: A change in DNA sequence. (e.g., sickle cell anemia caused by a single mutation in the hemoglobin gene)

title: Cell
description: The basic unit of life. (e.g., nerve cells, muscle cells, blood cells)

title: Prokaryotic Cell
description: A simple cell without a nucleus. (e.g., bacteria, archaea)

title: Eukaryotic Cell
description: A complex cell with a nucleus. (e.g., plant cells, animal cells, fungi, protists)

title: Plasma Membrane
description: The outer layer of a cell controlling substance entry. (e.g., made of a phospholipid bilayer)

title: Nucleus
description: The control center of a eukaryotic cell containing DNA. (e.g., found in human skin and liver cells)

title: Ribosome
description: A cell organelle that synthesizes proteins. (e.g., found in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells)

title: Mitochondrion
description: The powerhouse of the cell that produces energy. (e.g., more abundant in muscle cells for ATP production)

title: Chloroplast
description: An organelle in plant cells that performs photosynthesis. (e.g., found in green leaves of plants)

title: Endoplasmic Reticulum
description: A network involved in protein and lipid synthesis. (e.g., rough ER has ribosomes; smooth ER lacks ribosomes)

title: Golgi Apparatus
description: An organelle that modifies and transports proteins. (e.g., packages insulin for secretion in pancreatic cells)

title: Lysosome
description: A cell organelle containing digestive enzymes. (e.g., breaks down waste in white blood cells)

title: Peroxisome
description: An organelle that detoxifies harmful substances. (e.g., breaks down hydrogen peroxide in liver cells)

title: Cytoplasm
description: The fluid inside a cell that holds organelles. (e.g., contains enzymes and nutrients for cell metabolism)

title: Cytoskeleton
description: A network of fibers providing cell shape and movement. (e.g., actin filaments in muscle contraction)

title: Centrosome
description: An organelle organizing microtubules during cell division. (e.g., present in animal cells for spindle fiber formation)

title: Vacuole
description: A storage sac for nutrients and waste. (e.g., large central vacuole in plant cells stores water)

title: Cell Wall
description: A rigid layer providing support to plant cells. (e.g., made of cellulose in plants, chitin in fungi)

title: Plasmodesmata
description: Channels connecting plant cells for communication. (e.g., allow nutrient exchange in root tissues)

title: Tight Junctions
description: Connections sealing cells to prevent leaks. (e.g., found in the lining of intestines)

title: Gap Junctions
description: Channels allowing communication between animal cells. (e.g., in heart muscle cells for synchronized contraction)

title: Passive Transport
description: Movement of molecules without energy use. (e.g., diffusion of oxygen into cells)

title: Diffusion
description: Movement of molecules from high to low concentration. (e.g., perfume spreading in a room)

title: Osmosis
description: Water movement across a membrane from low to high solute concentration. (e.g., water absorption in plant roots)

title: Facilitated Diffusion
description: Passive transport using proteins. (e.g., glucose entry into cells via GLUT transporters)

title: Active Transport
description: Movement of molecules using energy (ATP). (e.g., sodium-potassium pump in nerve cells)

title: Endocytosis
description: The process of a cell engulfing materials. (e.g., white blood cells engulfing bacteria)

title: Phagocytosis
description: A type of endocytosis for large particles. (e.g., macrophages engulfing pathogens)

title: Pinocytosis
description: A type of endocytosis for liquids. (e.g., intestinal cells absorbing nutrients)

title: Exocytosis
description: The process of expelling substances from a cell. (e.g., secretion of insulin from pancreatic cells)

title: Aquaporins
description: Water channel proteins aiding osmosis. (e.g., present in kidney cells for water regulation)

title: Cell Cycle
description: The sequence of growth and division in a cell. (e.g., interphase and mitotic phase in human cells)

title: Interphase
description: The phase where the cell prepares for division. (e.g., DNA replication in S phase)

title: Mitosis
description: A process where a single cell divides into two identical cells. (e.g., skin cell regeneration after a cut)

title: Prophase
description: The first stage of mitosis where chromosomes condense. (e.g., nuclear membrane starts breaking down)

title: Metaphase
description: Chromosomes align in the middle of the cell. (e.g., spindle fibers attach to centromeres)

title: Anaphase
description: Chromosomes are pulled to opposite sides. (e.g., sister chromatids separate during this phase)

title: Telophase
description: The final stage where two nuclei form. (e.g., nuclear envelopes reforming around separated chromosomes)

title: Cytokinesis
description: The division of the cytoplasm into two cells. (e.g., cleavage furrow forms in animal cells, cell plate in plants)

title: Meiosis
description: Cell division producing four genetically unique cells. (e.g., occurs in sperm and egg cells during reproduction)

title: Crossing Over
description: Exchange of genetic material during meiosis. (e.g., increases genetic variation in offspring)

title: Prokaryote
description: A simple organism without a nucleus. (e.g., bacteria, archaea)

title: Eukaryote
description: A complex cell with a nucleus. (e.g., plant cells, animal cells, fungi, protists)

title: Bacterial Plasmid
description: Small circular DNA in bacteria. (e.g., used in genetic engineering for insulin production)

title: Capsule
description: A protective outer layer in some bacteria. (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae has a capsule for protection)

title: Flagella
description: A tail-like structure for movement. (e.g., sperm cells and bacterial cells like E. coli use flagella to move)

title: Pili
description: Hair-like structures for bacterial attachment. (e.g., bacteria use pili to stick to surfaces)

title: Binary Fission
description: Asexual reproduction in bacteria. (e.g., E. coli divides every 20 minutes)

title: Nucleoid Region
description: The area where DNA is found in prokaryotes. (e.g., bacterial chromosomes are in the nucleoid region)

title: Endospore
description: A tough bacterial structure for survival. (e.g., Bacillus anthracis forms endospores to resist harsh conditions)

title: Gram Staining
description: A technique to classify bacteria. (e.g., Gram-positive bacteria like Staphylococcus appear purple, Gram-negative like E. coli appear pink)

title: Cell Signaling
description: The process of cells communicating using molecules. (e.g., neurons releasing neurotransmitters for brain function)

title: Ligand
description: A molecule that binds to a receptor. (e.g., hormones like insulin binding to insulin receptors)

title: Receptor
description: A protein that receives signals. (e.g., dopamine receptors in the brain control mood)

title: G-Protein Coupled Receptor (GPCR)
description: A receptor involved in signal transduction. (e.g., adrenaline binds to GPCRs for fight-or-flight response)

title: Signal Transduction Pathway
description: The process of converting a signal into a cellular response. (e.g., insulin signaling glucose uptake in muscle cells)

title: Second Messenger
description: Molecules relaying signals inside cells. (e.g., cAMP in adrenaline response)

title: Autocrine Signaling
description: A cell signaling itself. (e.g., immune cells releasing cytokines to stimulate themselves)

title: Paracrine Signaling
description: Signaling between nearby cells. (e.g., neurotransmitters in synapses between nerve cells)

title: Endocrine Signaling
description: Long-distance signaling via the bloodstream. (e.g., insulin from the pancreas regulates blood sugar in distant cells)

title: Apoptosis
description: Programmed cell death. (e.g., elimination of damaged cells to prevent cancer)

title: Enzyme
description: A protein that speeds up biochemical reactions. (e.g., amylase breaks down starch into sugar)

title: Substrate
description: The molecule an enzyme acts upon. (e.g., starch is the substrate for amylase)

title: Active Site
description: The region where the enzyme binds to the substrate. (e.g., pepsin has a specific active site for protein digestion)

title: Lock and Key Model
description: The enzyme and substrate fit perfectly. (e.g., sucrase only acts on sucrose, like a key fitting a lock)

title: Induced Fit Model
description: The enzyme changes shape to fit the substrate. (e.g., hexokinase changes shape when binding glucose)

title: Cofactor
description: A non-protein helper for enzyme activity. (e.g., magnesium ions help DNA polymerase function)

title: Coenzyme
description: An organic molecule assisting enzymes. (e.g., Vitamin B12 helps in red blood cell formation)

title: Competitive Inhibition
description: A molecule blocks the active site. (e.g., sulfa drugs inhibit bacterial enzymes)

title: Non-Competitive Inhibition
description: A molecule binds elsewhere, altering enzyme shape. (e.g., cyanide inhibits cytochrome oxidase in respiration)

title: Allosteric Regulation
description: Molecules regulate enzyme activity by binding to a site other than the active site. (e.g., ATP regulates phosphofructokinase in glycolysis)

title: Metabolism
description: All chemical reactions in a cell. (e.g., digestion, respiration, protein synthesis)

title: Catabolism
description: The breakdown of molecules for energy. (e.g., glucose breakdown in cellular respiration)

title: Anabolism
description: The building of complex molecules. (e.g., protein synthesis from amino acids)

title: ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate)
description: The energy currency of the cell. (e.g., ATP powers muscle contraction and nerve impulses)

title: ADP (Adenosine Diphosphate)
description: The lower-energy form of ATP. (e.g., ADP is converted back to ATP in respiration)

title: Glycolysis
description: The process of breaking glucose into energy. (e.g., occurs in the cytoplasm, producing pyruvate and ATP)

title: Krebs Cycle (Citric Acid Cycle)
description: A metabolic pathway producing ATP and electron carriers. (e.g., occurs in mitochondria during respiration)

title: Electron Transport Chain
description: A sequence of reactions producing ATP. (e.g., occurs in the inner mitochondrial membrane)

title: Fermentation
description: Energy production in the absence of oxygen. (e.g., yeast fermentation produces ethanol and CO₂ in bread-making)

title: Photosynthesis
description: The process by which plants make food using sunlight. (e.g., occurs in chloroplasts, producing glucose and oxygen)

title: Plasma Membrane
description: A selectively permeable barrier controlling entry/exit of substances. (e.g., phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins)

title: Phospholipid Bilayer
description: A double-layered membrane with hydrophilic heads and hydrophobic tails. (e.g., cell membranes of all living organisms)

title: Integral Protein
description: A protein embedded in the membrane. (e.g., ion channels for sodium transport)

title: Peripheral Protein
description: A protein attached to the surface of the membrane. (e.g., involved in cell signaling and structure)

title: Glycoprotein
description: A protein with attached carbohydrate chains. (e.g., cell surface markers for immune response)

title: Cholesterol in Membranes
description: A lipid that maintains membrane fluidity. (e.g., prevents rigidity in cold temperatures)

title: Passive Transport
description: Movement of substances without energy. (e.g., diffusion of oxygen into cells)

title: Active Transport
description: Energy-requiring movement of molecules. (e.g., sodium-potassium pump in nerve cells)

title: Endocytosis
description: The process of engulfing materials into the cell. (e.g., macrophages engulf bacteria)

title: Exocytosis
description: The process of expelling substances from a cell. (e.g., neurons release neurotransmitters via exocytosis)

title: Cell Communication
description: The process by which cells interact using signals. (e.g., nerve cells transmitting electrical signals)

title: Receptor Protein
description: A protein that receives signals. (e.g., insulin receptor helps in glucose uptake)

title: Ligand
description: A signaling molecule that binds to a receptor. (e.g., hormones like adrenaline bind to GPCRs)

title: Second Messenger
description: A molecule relaying signals inside cells. (e.g., cAMP in adrenaline response)

title: Neurotransmitter
description: A chemical messenger between neurons. (e.g., dopamine affects mood and movement)

title: Hormone
description: A signaling molecule regulating body processes. (e.g., thyroid hormone controls metabolism)

title: Synaptic Signaling
description: A type of cell communication in the nervous system. (e.g., serotonin transmits signals in the brain)

title: Signal Transduction
description: The process of converting an external signal into a response. (e.g., insulin signaling for glucose metabolism)

title: G-Protein Coupled Receptor (GPCR)
description: A receptor involved in various cellular responses. (e.g., involved in vision, smell, and taste)

title: Cytokines
description: Signaling proteins regulating immune responses. (e.g., interleukins help in inflammation response)

title: DNA Replication
description: The process of copying DNA. (e.g., occurs before cell division in the S phase of interphase)

title: Helicase
description: An enzyme that unwinds DNA strands. (e.g., separates DNA strands at replication forks)

title: DNA Polymerase
description: An enzyme that adds nucleotides during replication. (e.g., DNA polymerase III synthesizes new DNA strands)

title: Leading Strand
description: The continuously synthesized DNA strand. (e.g., synthesized in the 5' to 3' direction)

title: Lagging Strand
description: The discontinuously synthesized DNA strand. (e.g., forms short Okazaki fragments)

title: Okazaki Fragments
description: Short DNA fragments formed on the lagging strand. (e.g., later joined by DNA ligase)

title: Telomere
description: The protective end of a chromosome. (e.g., telomeres shorten with aging in human cells)

title: Mutation
description: A change in DNA sequence. (e.g., sickle cell anemia results from a single base mutation)

title: Recombinant DNA
description: DNA from two different sources. (e.g., used in genetic engineering for insulin production)

title: Gene Expression
description: The process of making proteins from DNA. (e.g., transcription and translation in protein synthesis)

title: RNA (Ribonucleic Acid)
description: A nucleic acid involved in protein synthesis. (e.g., mRNA carries genetic instructions for making proteins)

title: mRNA (Messenger RNA)
description: Carries genetic code from DNA to ribosomes. (e.g., mRNA for insulin production in pancreatic cells)

title: tRNA (Transfer RNA)
description: Transfers amino acids to ribosomes during protein synthesis. (e.g., tRNA carrying methionine to start translation)

title: rRNA (Ribosomal RNA)
description: A structural component of ribosomes. (e.g., 16S rRNA helps in ribosome function in bacteria)

title: Transcription
description: The process of copying DNA into RNA. (e.g., occurs in the nucleus, producing mRNA)

title: RNA Polymerase
description: The enzyme that synthesizes RNA from DNA. (e.g., RNA polymerase II transcribes mRNA in eukaryotes)

title: Promoter Region
description: A DNA sequence where transcription starts. (e.g., TATA box in eukaryotic genes)

title: Translation
description: The process of converting mRNA into proteins. (e.g., occurs in ribosomes using amino acids)

title: Codon
description: A three-nucleotide sequence in mRNA coding for amino acids. (e.g., AUG is the start codon for methionine)

title: Anticodon
description: A complementary three-base sequence on tRNA. (e.g., UAC anticodon pairs with AUG start codon)

title: Protein
description: A biomolecule made of amino acids. (e.g., hemoglobin transports oxygen in blood)

title: Amino Acid
description: The building blocks of proteins. (e.g., lysine, leucine, and valine are essential amino acids)

title: Peptide Bond
description: A bond linking amino acids in proteins. (e.g., found in insulin, a peptide hormone)

title: Primary Structure
description: The linear sequence of amino acids in a protein. (e.g., insulin has a specific sequence of amino acids)

title: Secondary Structure
description: Local folding patterns in a protein. (e.g., alpha helices in keratin, beta sheets in silk)

title: Tertiary Structure
description: The overall 3D shape of a protein. (e.g., myoglobin has a globular structure for oxygen storage)

title: Quaternary Structure
description: Multiple protein subunits forming a functional protein. (e.g., hemoglobin has four subunits)

title: Denaturation
description: Loss of protein shape due to heat or chemicals. (e.g., egg whites coagulating when cooked)

title: Chaperone Proteins
description: Help proteins fold correctly. (e.g., heat shock proteins protect cells from stress)

title: Enzyme-Substrate Complex
description: The temporary binding of an enzyme and substrate. (e.g., amylase binds starch before breaking it down)

title: Cellular Respiration
description: The process of converting glucose into energy. (e.g., occurs in mitochondria, producing ATP)

title: Aerobic Respiration
description: ATP production using oxygen. (e.g., glucose oxidation in human muscle cells during exercise)

title: Anaerobic Respiration
description: ATP production without oxygen. (e.g., lactic acid fermentation in muscles during intense exercise)

title: Oxidation
description: Loss of electrons in a reaction. (e.g., glucose oxidation in respiration releases energy)

title: Reduction
description: Gain of electrons in a reaction. (e.g., NAD+ is reduced to NADH in glycolysis)

title: Electron Carrier
description: A molecule transferring electrons in respiration. (e.g., NADH and FADH₂ in mitochondria)

title: ATP Synthase
description: An enzyme producing ATP in mitochondria. (e.g., uses a proton gradient to generate ATP)

title: Chemiosmosis
description: The movement of protons to produce ATP. (e.g., occurs in oxidative phosphorylation during respiration)

title: Gluconeogenesis
description: The process of making glucose from non-carbohydrates. (e.g., liver cells produce glucose during fasting)

title: Beta-Oxidation
description: The breakdown of fatty acids for energy. (e.g., occurs in mitochondria when fats are used for fuel)

title: Cell Cycle Checkpoints
description: Control points ensuring proper cell division. (e.g., G1 checkpoint checks DNA integrity before replication)

title: Cyclins
description: Proteins that regulate the cell cycle. (e.g., cyclin D controls G1/S transition)

title: Cyclin-Dependent Kinases (CDKs)
description: Enzymes that control the cell cycle. (e.g., CDK2 regulates S phase entry)

title: p53 Protein
description: A tumor suppressor preventing abnormal cell growth. (e.g., mutations in p53 lead to cancer)

title: Oncogene
description: A gene that promotes cancer when mutated. (e.g., Ras oncogene drives uncontrolled cell division)

title: Tumor Suppressor Gene
description: A gene that prevents cancer. (e.g., BRCA1 mutations increase breast cancer risk)

title: Metastasis
description: The spread of cancer cells to other parts of the body. (e.g., lung cancer spreading to the liver)

title: Apoptosis
description: Programmed cell death preventing abnormal growth. (e.g., eliminates damaged skin cells after sunburn)

title: Carcinogen
description: A substance that causes cancer. (e.g., tobacco smoke contains carcinogens like benzopyrene)

title: Radiation Therapy
description: The use of radiation to kill cancer cells. (e.g., used in treating brain tumors)

title: Stem Cell
description: An undifferentiated cell capable of becoming specialized. (e.g., embryonic stem cells develop into different tissues)

title: Totipotent Stem Cell
description: A cell that can become any cell type. (e.g., fertilized egg developing into an entire organism)

title: Pluripotent Stem Cell
description: A cell that can become any body cell except placenta. (e.g., embryonic stem cells form organs)

title: Multipotent Stem Cell
description: A cell that can become a limited number of cells. (e.g., bone marrow stem cells form blood cells)

title: Differentiation
description: The process where a cell becomes specialized. (e.g., nerve cells develop axons for signal transmission)

title: Neural Stem Cells
description: Stem cells that develop into neurons. (e.g., used in research for treating brain injuries)

title: Hematopoietic Stem Cells
description: Stem cells that produce blood cells. (e.g., found in bone marrow and used in transplants)

title: Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells (iPSCs)
description: Mature cells reprogrammed into stem cells. (e.g., skin cells converted into iPSCs for regenerative medicine)

title: Regenerative Medicine
description: Using stem cells to repair tissues. (e.g., growing new heart tissue for transplant patients)

title: Organ Culture
description: Growing organs in a lab using tissue engineering. (e.g., lab-grown skin grafts for burn victims)

title: DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)
description: A molecule carrying genetic information. (e.g., human DNA contains genes for eye color, height, etc.)

title: RNA (Ribonucleic Acid)
description: A single-stranded nucleic acid involved in protein synthesis. (e.g., mRNA carries genetic codes for hemoglobin production)

title: Nucleotide
description: The building block of DNA and RNA. (e.g., adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine in DNA)

title: Double Helix
description: The twisted-ladder structure of DNA. (e.g., discovered by Watson and Crick in 1953)

title: Sugar-Phosphate Backbone
description: The structural framework of DNA and RNA. (e.g., deoxyribose in DNA, ribose in RNA)

title: Base Pair
description: A pair of nucleotides connected by hydrogen bonds. (e.g., A-T and G-C pairs in DNA)

title: Adenine (A)
description: A nitrogenous base in DNA and RNA. (e.g., pairs with thymine in DNA and uracil in RNA)

title: Thymine (T)
description: A nitrogenous base in DNA. (e.g., pairs with adenine in DNA but absent in RNA)

title: Cytosine (C)
description: A nitrogenous base found in both DNA and RNA. (e.g., pairs with guanine in DNA and RNA)

title: Guanine (G)
description: A nitrogenous base in DNA and RNA. (e.g., pairs with cytosine in both nucleic acids)

title: Uracil (U)
description: A nitrogenous base found only in RNA. (e.g., pairs with adenine in RNA instead of thymine)

title: Deoxyribose
description: A sugar molecule in DNA. (e.g., forms part of the DNA backbone, different from ribose in RNA)

title: Ribose
description: A sugar molecule in RNA. (e.g., found in ATP and RNA nucleotides)

title: Hydrogen Bond
description: A weak bond between nitrogenous bases in DNA. (e.g., holds A-T and G-C pairs together in the double helix)

title: Phosphodiester Bond
description: A strong bond linking nucleotides in DNA and RNA. (e.g., forms the backbone of nucleic acids)

title: Antiparallel Strands
description: DNA strands run in opposite directions. (e.g., one strand runs 5' to 3', the other 3' to 5')

title: 3' End
description: The end of a DNA strand with a free hydroxyl group. (e.g., essential for DNA replication)

title: 5' End
description: The end of a DNA strand with a phosphate group. (e.g., the starting point for DNA synthesis)

title: Chargaff’s Rule
description: The principle that A pairs with T and G pairs with C. (e.g., helps maintain base pairing in DNA replication)

title: Central Dogma
description: The flow of genetic information: DNA → RNA → Protein. (e.g., explains gene expression in living organisms)

title: Genetic Engineering
description: The modification of an organism’s DNA. (e.g., inserting insulin-producing genes into bacteria)

title: Recombinant DNA
description: DNA formed by combining genes from different sources. (e.g., human insulin gene in bacterial plasmids)

title: Plasmid
description: A small, circular DNA molecule in bacteria used in genetic engineering. (e.g., pBR322 used in cloning experiments)

title: Vector
description: A carrier used to transfer genetic material. (e.g., plasmids or viruses as gene delivery systems)

title: Restriction Enzyme
description: An enzyme that cuts DNA at specific sites. (e.g., EcoRI recognizes and cuts GAATTC sequences)

title: Sticky Ends
description: Single-stranded DNA overhangs after enzyme cutting. (e.g., created by EcoRI for easy gene insertion)

title: Blunt Ends
description: DNA fragments without overhangs. (e.g., produced by restriction enzyme HaeIII)

title: DNA Ligase
description: An enzyme that joins DNA fragments. (e.g., used in recombinant DNA technology to seal cut DNA)

title: Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)
description: A method to amplify DNA. (e.g., used in forensic DNA testing)

title: Gel Electrophoresis
description: A technique to separate DNA fragments by size. (e.g., used in paternity testing and crime scene analysis)

title: Transformation
description: The uptake of foreign DNA by a cell. (e.g., bacterial uptake of recombinant plasmids in genetic engineering)

title: Gene Cloning
description: The process of making identical copies of a gene. (e.g., cloning the insulin gene for diabetes treatment)

title: Genomic Library
description: A collection of cloned DNA fragments from an organism. (e.g., used to study genetic diseases)

title: cDNA (Complementary DNA)
description: DNA synthesized from mRNA. (e.g., used to express eukaryotic genes in bacteria)

title: Gene Therapy
description: The use of genes to treat diseases. (e.g., replacing defective genes in cystic fibrosis patients)

title: Knockout Gene
description: A gene that has been completely inactivated. (e.g., knockout mice for studying genetic diseases)

title: Reporter Gene
description: A gene used to track expression. (e.g., GFP (Green Fluorescent Protein) in cell biology studies)

title: Southern Blotting
description: A technique to detect specific DNA sequences. (e.g., used in forensic DNA fingerprinting)

title: CRISPR-Cas9
description: A powerful gene-editing tool. (e.g., used to correct genetic defects in diseases like sickle cell anemia)

title: Gene Editing
description: The process of altering DNA sequences in living organisms. (e.g., CRISPR is used for precise gene modifications)

title: Mutation
description: A permanent change in the DNA sequence. (e.g., sickle cell anemia caused by a point mutation in the HBB gene)

title: Point Mutation
description: A change in a single nucleotide. (e.g., GAG → GTG in sickle cell disease)

title: Substitution Mutation
description: One nucleotide is replaced with another. (e.g., A replaces G, leading to an altered protein)

title: Insertion Mutation
description: Addition of extra nucleotides in a DNA sequence. (e.g., Huntington’s disease caused by CAG repeats)

title: Deletion Mutation
description: Removal of nucleotides from a DNA sequence. (e.g., cystic fibrosis caused by the deletion of three bases in CFTR gene)

title: Frameshift Mutation
description: Insertion or deletion of nucleotides that shifts the reading frame. (e.g., Tay-Sachs disease caused by a four-base insertion)

title: Silent Mutation
description: A change in DNA that does not affect protein function. (e.g., AAA → AAG, both coding for lysine)

title: Missense Mutation
description: A mutation that results in a different amino acid. (e.g., sickle cell anemia changes glutamic acid to valine)

title: Nonsense Mutation
description: A mutation that creates a premature stop codon. (e.g., Duchenne muscular dystrophy caused by a nonsense mutation in the dystrophin gene)

title: Splice Site Mutation
description: A mutation affecting the way exons are joined. (e.g., beta-thalassemia caused by incorrect RNA splicing)

title: Duplication Mutation
description: A section of DNA is copied multiple times. (e.g., Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease due to duplication of the PMP22 gene)

title: Inversion Mutation
description: A DNA segment is reversed in orientation. (e.g., hemophilia A caused by an inversion in the F8 gene)

title: Translocation Mutation
description: A segment of DNA moves to a new location. (e.g., chronic myeloid leukemia caused by the Philadelphia chromosome translocation)

title: Mutagen
description: An agent that causes mutations. (e.g., UV radiation causing skin cancer by damaging DNA)

title: Spontaneous Mutation
description: A mutation occurring naturally without external influence. (e.g., errors in DNA replication leading to mutations in bacteria)

title: Induced Mutation
description: A mutation caused by environmental factors. (e.g., tobacco smoke chemicals causing lung cancer mutations)

title: Germline Mutation
description: A mutation passed from parents to offspring. (e.g., BRCA1 gene mutations increasing breast cancer risk)

title: Somatic Mutation
description: A mutation occurring in body cells, not inherited. (e.g., mutations leading to skin cancer due to UV exposure)

title: Lethal Mutation
description: A mutation that causes death. (e.g., certain Tay-Sachs mutations leading to early childhood death)

title: Conditional Mutation
description: A mutation that affects an organism under specific conditions. (e.g., temperature-sensitive mutations in bacteria that only manifest at high temperatures)

title: Genetically Modified Organism (GMO)
description: An organism with altered DNA. (e.g., Bt cotton engineered to resist pests)

title: Transgenic Organism
description: An organism carrying a foreign gene. (e.g., GloFish, which contains jellyfish genes for fluorescence)

title: Bt Crops
description: Crops genetically modified with Bacillus thuringiensis genes for pest resistance. (e.g., Bt corn used to kill corn borers)

title: Herbicide-Resistant Crops
description: Plants modified to tolerate herbicides. (e.g., Roundup Ready soybeans resistant to glyphosate)

title: Golden Rice
description: Genetically modified rice enriched with vitamin A. (e.g., developed to reduce vitamin A deficiency in children)

title: Flavr Savr Tomato
description: The first genetically modified food approved for sale. (e.g., engineered for longer shelf life by reducing softening)

title: Biopharming
description: Using GMOs to produce pharmaceuticals. (e.g., genetically modified goats producing human insulin in milk)

title: Gene Drive
description: A genetic engineering technique that spreads modified genes rapidly. (e.g., used to control mosquito populations by altering reproduction genes)

title: Knock-in Organism
description: An organism with a specific gene added. (e.g., lab mice with human disease genes for research purposes)

title: Knockout Organism
description: An organism with a specific gene removed or inactivated. (e.g., knockout mice used to study gene functions in disease research)

title: Edible Vaccines
description: Genetically modified plants producing vaccines. (e.g., banana plants engineered to produce hepatitis B vaccine)

title: Gene Silencing
description: A technique to turn off specific genes. (e.g., RNA interference (RNAi) used to suppress virus infections in plants)

title: CRISPR Agriculture
description: Gene-editing crops for improved traits. (e.g., drought-resistant wheat developed using CRISPR-Cas9)

title: Hybrid Crops
description: Plants created by crossbreeding different species. (e.g., hybrid maize for higher yield and disease resistance)

title: Biofortification
description: Increasing the nutritional value of crops using biotechnology. (e.g., iron-fortified wheat to combat anemia)

title: Animal Cloning
description: Creating genetically identical animals. (e.g., Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal from an adult cell)

title: Somatic Cell Nuclear Transfer (SCNT)
description: A cloning technique using a somatic cell nucleus. (e.g., used in cloning animals like sheep and cows)

title: Synthetic Biology
description: Designing and creating new biological parts and systems. (e.g., synthetic bacteria engineered to produce biofuels)

title: Ethical Concerns in GMOs
description: Debates on safety, environmental impact, and ethics of modifying organisms. (e.g., concerns about GM food labeling and consumer choice)

title: Biosafety Regulations
description: Rules governing the use of GMOs. (e.g., India's Genetic Engineering Appraisal Committee (GEAC) monitors GM crop approvals)

title: DNA Replication
description: The process of copying DNA before cell division. (e.g., occurs in the S-phase of the cell cycle)

title: Semiconservative Replication
description: Each new DNA molecule consists of one old and one new strand. (e.g., confirmed by the Meselson-Stahl experiment)

title: Helicase
description: An enzyme that unwinds the DNA helix. (e.g., breaks hydrogen bonds between base pairs in replication)

title: DNA Polymerase
description: An enzyme that synthesizes new DNA strands. (e.g., DNA polymerase III in bacteria extends new DNA strands)

title: Leading Strand
description: The continuously synthesized DNA strand. (e.g., replicated in the 5’ to 3’ direction towards the replication fork)

title: Lagging Strand
description: The strand synthesized in short fragments. (e.g., Okazaki fragments are formed on this strand)

title: Okazaki Fragments
description: Short DNA fragments on the lagging strand. (e.g., joined by DNA ligase to complete replication)

title: Primase
description: An enzyme that synthesizes RNA primers. (e.g., provides starting points for DNA polymerase)

title: Topoisomerase
description: An enzyme that prevents DNA supercoiling. (e.g., relieves strain ahead of the replication fork)

title: Replication Fork
description: The Y-shaped region where DNA is unwound and replicated. (e.g., expands during DNA replication in prokaryotes and eukaryotes)

title: Transcription
description: The process of converting DNA into RNA. (e.g., occurs in the nucleus in eukaryotic cells)

title: RNA Polymerase
description: An enzyme that synthesizes RNA from DNA. (e.g., RNA polymerase II transcribes mRNA in eukaryotes)

title: mRNA (Messenger RNA)
description: Carries genetic information from DNA to ribosomes. (e.g., codes for hemoglobin protein synthesis in red blood cells)

title: tRNA (Transfer RNA)
description: Transfers amino acids to ribosomes during protein synthesis. (e.g., carries methionine to start translation)

title: rRNA (Ribosomal RNA)
description: A component of ribosomes that helps in protein synthesis. (e.g., forms the structural part of the 70S and 80S ribosomes)

title: Codon
description: A sequence of three nucleotides coding for an amino acid. (e.g., AUG is the start codon for translation)

title: Anticodon
description: A sequence of three nucleotides on tRNA that pairs with an mRNA codon. (e.g., UAC pairs with the start codon AUG)

title: Promoter
description: A DNA sequence where RNA polymerase binds to initiate transcription. (e.g., TATA box in eukaryotes aids transcription initiation)

title: Terminator
description: A DNA sequence that signals the end of transcription. (e.g., hairpin loop structures in bacterial termination)

title: Introns
description: Non-coding sequences in eukaryotic genes. (e.g., removed during RNA splicing in eukaryotic cells)

title: Exons
description: Coding regions in genes that remain in mRNA. (e.g., translated into proteins after splicing)

title: Splicing
description: The removal of introns from mRNA. (e.g., performed by the spliceosome in eukaryotic cells)

title: Translation
description: The process of synthesizing proteins from mRNA. (e.g., occurs in ribosomes in the cytoplasm)

title: Ribosome
description: A cellular structure that assembles proteins. (e.g., consists of a large and small subunit in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes)

title: Peptide Bond
description: A bond linking amino acids in a protein. (e.g., forms between glycine and alanine in polypeptides)

title: Gene Expression
description: The process by which genes produce proteins. (e.g., regulated to ensure proper cellular function)

title: Operon
description: A cluster of genes controlled by a single promoter. (e.g., the lac operon in E. coli regulates lactose metabolism)

title: Lac Operon
description: A bacterial gene system controlling lactose digestion. (e.g., activated in the presence of lactose)

title: Repressor
description: A protein that blocks gene transcription. (e.g., the lac repressor inhibits the lac operon when lactose is absent)

title: Enhancer
description: A DNA sequence that boosts gene transcription. (e.g., enhances RNA polymerase binding for efficient gene activation)

title: Silencer
description: A DNA sequence that suppresses gene transcription. (e.g., involved in turning off certain genes in development)

title: Epigenetics
description: The study of heritable changes in gene expression without DNA sequence changes. (e.g., DNA methylation affecting gene activity)

title: DNA Methylation
description: The addition of methyl groups to DNA to regulate gene activity. (e.g., hypermethylation can silence tumor suppressor genes in cancer)

title: Histone Modification
description: Chemical changes to histones affecting chromatin structure. (e.g., acetylation leads to gene activation)

title: Chromatin Remodelling
description: The process of altering chromatin structure to regulate gene access. (e.g., euchromatin is transcriptionally active while heterochromatin is inactive)

title: Gene Therapy
description: The use of genes to treat diseases. (e.g., used to treat cystic fibrosis by replacing faulty CFTR genes)

title: Ex Vivo Gene Therapy
description: Genetic modification of cells outside the body before reintroducing them. (e.g., treating blood disorders using modified stem cells)

title: In Vivo Gene Therapy
description: Directly delivering genes into the patient’s body. (e.g., using viral vectors to treat retinal disorders)

title: Viral Vector
description: A virus used to deliver therapeutic genes. (e.g., adenovirus vectors in COVID-19 vaccines)

title: Non-Viral Vector
description: A non-infectious carrier for gene transfer. (e.g., lipid nanoparticles in mRNA vaccines)

title: Stem Cell Therapy
description: Using stem cells to regenerate damaged tissues. (e.g., bone marrow transplants for leukemia patients)

title: CRISPR Gene Editing
description: A precise gene-editing technology. (e.g., correcting sickle cell mutations in human cells)

title: Personalized Medicine
description: Tailoring treatments based on a patient’s genetic makeup. (e.g., targeted cancer therapies like HER2 inhibitors for breast cancer)

title: Pharmacogenomics
description: The study of how genes affect drug responses. (e.g., CYP450 gene variations influencing drug metabolism)

title: Genetic Screening
description: Testing individuals for specific genetic conditions. (e.g., BRCA gene testing for breast cancer risk assessment)

title: Recombinant DNA Technology
description: Combining DNA from different sources to create new genetic combinations. (e.g., production of insulin in bacteria using human genes)

title: Vector
description: A DNA molecule used to transfer foreign genes into a host cell. (e.g., plasmids in bacterial transformation)

title: Plasmid
description: A small circular DNA molecule found in bacteria used in genetic engineering. (e.g., pBR322 is a commonly used plasmid vector)

title: Restriction Enzyme
description: An enzyme that cuts DNA at specific sequences. (e.g., EcoRI cuts at GAATTC sites in DNA)

title: Sticky Ends
description: Overhanging single-stranded DNA fragments after restriction enzyme cuts. (e.g., used for DNA ligation in cloning experiments)

title: Blunt Ends
description: DNA fragments with no overhangs after restriction digestion. (e.g., created by enzymes like Al uI and HaeIII)

title: DNA Ligase
description: An enzyme that joins DNA fragments. (e.g., used to insert genes into plasmids in recombinant DNA experiments)

title: Transformation
description: The uptake of foreign DNA by a cell. (e.g., bacteria taking up plasmids containing antibiotic resistance genes)

title: Electroporation
description: Using electrical pulses to introduce DNA into cells. (e.g., used in plant and bacterial transformation techniques)

title: Gene Cloning
description: Making multiple copies of a specific gene. (e.g., cloning insulin genes for diabetes treatment)

title: Expression Vector
description: A plasmid designed to produce a protein from an inserted gene. (e.g., used in recombinant protein production in bacteria)

title: Reporter Gene
description: A gene used to measure gene expression. (e.g., GFP (Green Fluorescent Protein) in molecular biology experiments)

title: Selectable Marker
description: A gene that allows scientists to identify successful transformations. (e.g., antibiotic resistance genes in plasmids)

title: Gene Knockout
description: Deleting a specific gene to study its function. (e.g., knockout mice used in disease research)

title: Gene Knock-in
description: Adding a specific gene into an organism’s genome. (e.g., inserting human genes into animal models for medical research)

title: CRISPR-Cas9
description: A precise genome-editing tool derived from bacteria. (e.g., used to correct genetic defects in human cells)

title: Guide RNA (gRNA)
description: A small RNA molecule that directs the Cas9 enzyme to a specific DNA sequence. (e.g., designed to target and cut faulty genes)

title: Cas9 Enzyme
description: A protein that cuts DNA at specific sites in CRISPR technology. (e.g., used for gene editing in plants and animals)

title: Knockout CRISPR
description: A method using CRISPR to disable genes. (e.g., used to study the function of disease-related genes)

title: Base Editing
description: A CRISPR technique that changes a single DNA base without cutting the strand. (e.g., converting adenine to guanine to correct genetic mutations)

title: Prime Editing
description: An advanced gene-editing method that allows precise DNA modifications without double-strand breaks. (e.g., correcting sickle cell disease mutations more efficiently than CRISPR-Cas9)

title: Gene Drive
description: A genetic engineering method that spreads a gene rapidly in a population. (e.g., used to reduce mosquito populations carrying malaria)

title: CRISPR in Agriculture
description: Gene-editing crops for better traits. (e.g., developing drought-resistant rice varieties)

title: CRISPR in Medicine
description: Treating genetic disorders through precise DNA modification. (e.g., experimental therapies for sickle cell anemia and muscular dystrophy)

title: Ethical Concerns in CRISPR
description: Debates on the safety and ethics of human genome editing. (e.g., concerns about editing human embryos for non-medical purposes)

title: Genomics
description: The study of entire genomes, including genes and their functions. (e.g., Human Genome Project mapped all human genes)

title: Functional Genomics
description: Researching how genes and their products function in biological processes. (e.g., studying gene regulation in cancer cells)

title: Comparative Genomics
description: Comparing genomes of different species. (e.g., human and chimpanzee DNA similarity studies)

title: Metagenomics
description: Studying genetic material from environmental samples. (e.g., analyzing microbial communities in soil or the human gut)

title: Transcriptomics
description: The study of all RNA molecules in a cell or organism. (e.g., identifying active genes in different tissues)

title: Proteomics
description: The study of proteins expressed by a genome. (e.g., analyzing protein pathways in cancer cells)

title: Epigenomics
description: The study of chemical modifications affecting gene activity. (e.g., investigating DNA methylation in aging processes)

title: Bioinformatics
description: Using computational tools to analyze biological data. (e.g., BLAST software used for DNA sequence comparison)

title: Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS)
description: A high-throughput DNA sequencing technology. (e.g., used in personalized medicine for cancer treatment)

title: Microarray Technology
description: A method to study gene expression on a large scale. (e.g., used in cancer research to identify active genes in tumors)

title: Industrial Biotechnology
description: Using genetic engineering to produce chemicals and enzymes. (e.g., yeast modified to produce bioethanol)

title: Environmental Biotechnology
description: Using genetically engineered organisms to clean pollution. (e.g., bacteria modified to break down oil spills in bioremediation)

title: Agricultural Biotechnology
description: Genetic modification of crops for better yield and resistance. (e.g., pest-resistant Bt cotton)

title: Medical Biotechnology
description: Using genetic engineering to develop treatments and diagnostics. (e.g., CRISPR-based therapies for genetic diseases)

title: Gene Silencing

description: Modifying gene expression without changing DNA sequences. (e.g., CRISPR-based DNA methylation for controlling gene activity)
